dn5:1.0.eng: 1. The Brahmins and Householders of Khāṇumata

dn5:1.1.comm: When asked about sacrifice, the Buddha tells a story of how a king was persuaded to forgo cruelty and institute a constructive social policy of welfare instead.

dn5:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā magadhesu cārikaṃ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi yena khāṇumataṃ nāma magadhānaṃ brāhmaṇagāmo tadavasari.
dn5:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Magadhans together with a large Saṅgha of five hundred mendicants when he arrived at a village of the Magadhan brahmins named Khāṇumata.
dn5:1.2.comm: Khāṇumata is only mentioned here. It means “stumpy”, perhaps indicating that it was, or had recently been, a rough out-of-the-way place.

dn5:1.3.pli: Tatra sudaṃ bhagavā khāṇumate viharati ambalaṭṭhikāyaṃ.
dn5:1.3.eng: There he stayed nearby at Ambalaṭṭhikā.
dn5:1.3.comm: The commentary says this was similar to the Ambalaṭṭhikā of DN 1:1.2.1.

dn5:1.4.pli: Tena kho pana samayena kūṭadanto brāhmaṇo khāṇumataṃ ajjhāvasati sattussadaṃ satiṇakaṭṭhodakaṃ sadhaññaṃ rājabhoggaṃ raññā māgadhena seniyena bimbisārena dinnaṃ rājadāyaṃ brahmadeyyaṃ.
dn5:1.4.eng: Now at that time the brahmin Kūṭadanta was living in Khāṇumata. It was a crown property given by King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha, teeming with living creatures, full of hay, wood, water, and grain, a royal park endowed to a brahmin.
dn5:1.4.comm: Like the town Khāṇumata, the brahmin Kūṭadanta appears only here. His name means “pointy teeth”, but there is no evidence that he was a vampire.

dn5:1.5.pli: Tena kho pana samayena kūṭadantassa brāhmaṇassa mahāyañño upakkhaṭo hoti.
dn5:1.5.eng: Now at that time Kūṭadanta had prepared a great sacrifice.

dn5:1.6.pli: Satta ca usabhasatāni satta ca vacchatarasatāni satta ca vacchatarīsatāni satta ca ajasatāni satta ca urabbhasatāni thūṇūpanītāni honti yaññatthāya.
dn5:1.6.eng: Bulls, bullocks, heifers, goats and rams—seven hundred of each—had been led to the post for the sacrifice.
dn5:1.6.comm: At Snp 2.7:26.1, the sacrifice of cows in particular was said to be the nadir of decline for brahmins. When similar sacrifices are described elsewhere in the canon, the number is five hundred rather than seven hundred (SN 3.9:1.2, AN 7.47:1.2).

dn5:2.1.eng: The brahmins and householders of Khāṇumata heard:

dn5:2.2.pli: “samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo sakyaputto sakyakulā pabbajito magadhesu cārikaṃ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi khāṇumataṃ anuppatto khāṇumate viharati ambalaṭṭhikāyaṃ.
dn5:2.2.eng: “It seems the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—has arrived at Khāṇumata and is staying at Ambalaṭṭhikā.

dn5:2.3.pli: Taṃ kho pana bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ evaṃ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:

dn5:2.4.pli: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’ti.
dn5:2.4.eng: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’

dn5:2.5.pli: So imaṃ lokaṃ sadevakaṃ samārakaṃ sabrahmakaṃ sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṃ pajaṃ sadevamanussaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti.
dn5:2.5.eng: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.

dn5:2.6.pli: So dhammaṃ deseti ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāseti.
dn5:2.6.eng: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.

dn5:2.7.pli: Sādhu kho pana tathārūpānaṃ arahataṃ dassanaṃ hotī”ti.
dn5:2.7.eng: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”

dn5:2.8.pli: Atha kho khāṇumatakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā khāṇumatā nikkhamitvā saṅghasaṅghī gaṇībhūtā yena ambalaṭṭhikā tenupasaṅkamanti.
dn5:2.8.eng: Then, exiting Khāṇumata, they formed into companies and headed to Ambalaṭṭhikā.

dn5:3.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena kūṭadanto brāhmaṇo uparipāsāde divāseyyaṃ upagato hoti.
dn5:3.1.eng: Now at that time the brahmin Kūṭadanta had retired to the upper floor of his stilt longhouse for his midday nap.

dn5:3.2.pli: Addasā kho kūṭadanto brāhmaṇo khāṇumatake brāhmaṇagahapatike khāṇumatā nikkhamitvā saṅghasaṅghī gaṇībhūte yena ambalaṭṭhikā tenupasaṅkamante.
dn5:3.2.eng: He saw the brahmins and householders heading for Ambalaṭṭhikā,

dn5:3.4.pli: “kiṃ nu kho, bho khatte, khāṇumatakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā khāṇumatā nikkhamitvā saṅghasaṅghī gaṇībhūtā yena ambalaṭṭhikā tenupasaṅkamantī”ti?
dn5:3.4.eng: “My butler, why are the brahmins and householders headed for Ambalaṭṭhikā?”

dn5:3.5.pli: “Atthi kho, bho, samaṇo gotamo sakyaputto sakyakulā pabbajito magadhesu cārikaṃ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi khāṇumataṃ anuppatto, khāṇumate viharati ambalaṭṭhikāyaṃ.
dn5:3.5.eng: “The ascetic Gotama has arrived at Khāṇumata and is staying at Ambalaṭṭhikā.

dn5:3.6.pli: Taṃ kho pana bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ evaṃ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:

dn5:3.7.pli: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’ti.
dn5:3.7.eng: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’

dn5:3.8.eng: They’re going to see that worthy Gotama.”

dn5:4.3.eng: the ascetic Gotama knows how to accomplish the sacrifice with three modes and sixteen accessories.
dn5:4.3.comm: News of the Buddha had spread in Brahmanical circles. In DN 3 we saw the Buddha use his rhetorical technique of adapting his teaching to reframe Brahmanical doctrines in order to establish a common ground. Here we see the downside to such techniques, as the details of the reframing have been lost.

dn5:4.4.pli: Na kho panāhaṃ jānāmi tividhaṃ yaññasampadaṃ soḷasaparikkhāraṃ.

dn5:4.5.eng: but I wish to perform a great sacrifice.

dn5:4.6.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ upasaṅkamitvā tividhaṃ yaññasampadaṃ soḷasaparikkhāraṃ puccheyyan”ti.
dn5:4.6.eng: Why don’t I ask him how to accomplish the sacrifice with three modes and sixteen accessories?”
dn5:4.6.comm: No such sacrifice has been identified in Brahmanical texts.

dn5:4.7.pli: Atha kho kūṭadanto brāhmaṇo khattaṃ āmantesi:

dn5:4.8.pli: “tena hi, bho khatte, yena khāṇumatakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā tenupasaṅkama. upasaṅkamitvā khāṇumatake brāhmaṇagahapatike evaṃ vadehi:
dn5:4.8.eng: “Well then, go to the brahmins and householders and say to them:

dn5:4.10.pli: āgamentu kira bhavanto, kūṭadantopi brāhmaṇo samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamissatī’”ti.
dn5:4.10.eng: you to wait, as he will also go to see the ascetic Gotama.’”

dn5:4.11.pli: “Evaṃ, bho”ti kho so khattā kūṭadantassa brāhmaṇassa paṭissutvā yena khāṇumatakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā tenupasaṅkami. upasaṅkamitvā khāṇumatake brāhmaṇagahapatike etadavoca:
dn5:4.11.eng: “Yes, worthy sir,” replied the butler, and did as he was asked.

dn5:4.13.pli: ‘āgamentu kira bhonto, kūṭadantopi brāhmaṇo samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamissatī’”ti.

dn5:5.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena anekāni brāhmaṇasatāni khāṇumate paṭivasanti:
dn5:5.1.eng: Now at that time several hundred brahmins were residing in Khāṇumata

dn5:5.2.eng: thinking to participate in Kūṭadanta’s sacrifice.

dn5:5.4.pli: “kūṭadanto kira brāhmaṇo samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamissatī”ti.
dn5:5.4.eng: Kūṭadanta was going to see the ascetic Gotama.

dn5:5.5.pli: Atha kho te brāhmaṇā yena kūṭadanto brāhmaṇo tenupasaṅkamiṃsu. upasaṅkamitvā kūṭadantaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ etadavocuṃ:
dn5:5.5.eng: They approached Kūṭadanta and said to him:

dn5:5.6.pli: “saccaṃ kira bhavaṃ kūṭadanto samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamissatī”ti?
dn5:5.6.eng: “Is it really true that you are going to see the ascetic Gotama?”

dn5:6.1.pli: “Mā bhavaṃ kūṭadanto samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkami.

dn5:6.2.pli: Na arahati bhavaṃ kūṭadanto samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ.
dn5:6.2.eng: It’s not appropriate for you to go to see the ascetic Gotama.

dn5:6.3.pli: Sace bhavaṃ kūṭadanto samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamissati, bhoto kūṭadantassa yaso hāyissati, samaṇassa gotamassa yaso abhivaḍḍhissati.
dn5:6.3.eng: For if you do so, your reputation will diminish and his will increase.

dn5:6.4.pli: Yampi bhoto kūṭadantassa yaso hāyissati, samaṇassa gotamassa yaso abhivaḍḍhissati, imināpaṅgena na arahati bhavaṃ kūṭadanto samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ.
dn5:6.4.eng: For this reason it’s not appropriate for you to go to see the ascetic Gotama;

dn5:6.5.pli: Samaṇo tveva gotamo arahati bhavantaṃ kūṭadantaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ.
dn5:6.5.eng: it’s appropriate that he comes to see you.

dn5:6.6.pli: Bhavañhi kūṭadanto ubhato sujāto mātito ca pitito ca saṃsuddhagahaṇiko yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā akkhitto anupakkuṭṭho jātivādena.
dn5:6.6.eng: You are well born on both your mother’s and father’s side, of pure descent, with irrefutable and impeccable genealogy back to the seventh paternal generation.

dn5:6.7.pli: Yampi bhavaṃ kūṭadanto ubhato sujāto mātito ca pitito ca saṃsuddhagahaṇiko yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā akkhitto anupakkuṭṭho jātivādena, imināpaṅgena na arahati bhavaṃ kūṭadanto samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ.
dn5:6.7.eng: For this reason it’s not appropriate for you to go to see the ascetic Gotama;

dn5:6.8.pli: Samaṇo tveva gotamo arahati bhavantaṃ kūṭadantaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ.
dn5:6.8.eng: it’s appropriate that he comes to see you.

dn5:6.9.pli: Bhavañhi kūṭadanto aḍḍho mahaddhano mahābhogo pahūtavittūpakaraṇo pahūtajātarūparajato …pe…
dn5:6.9.eng: You’re rich, affluent, and wealthy, with lots of property and assets, and lots of money and grain …

dn5:6.10.pli: Bhavañhi kūṭadanto ajjhāyako mantadharo tiṇṇaṃ vedānaṃ pāragū sanighaṇḍukeṭubhānaṃ sākkharappabhedānaṃ itihāsapañcamānaṃ padako veyyākaraṇo lokāyatamahāpurisalakkhaṇesu anavayo …pe…
dn5:6.10.eng: You recite and remember the hymns, and have mastered the three Vedas, together with their vocabularies and ritual performance, their phonology and word classification, and the testaments as fifth. You know them word-by-word, and their grammar. You are well versed in cosmology and the marks of a great man. …

dn5:6.11.pli: Bhavañhi kūṭadanto abhirūpo dassanīyo pāsādiko paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgato brahmavaṇṇī brahmavacchasī akhuddāvakāso dassanāya …pe…
dn5:6.11.eng: You are attractive, good-looking, lovely, of surpassing beauty. You have divine looks and lustre, remarkable to behold. …

dn5:6.12.pli: Bhavañhi kūṭadanto sīlavā vuddhasīlī vuddhasīlena samannāgato …pe…
dn5:6.12.eng: You are ethical, mature in ethical conduct. …

dn5:6.13.pli: Bhavañhi kūṭadanto kalyāṇavāco kalyāṇavākkaraṇo poriyā vācāya samannāgato vissaṭṭhāya anelagalāya atthassa viññāpaniyā …pe…
dn5:6.13.eng: You’re a good speaker who enunciates well, with a polished, clear, and articulate voice that expresses the meaning. …

dn5:6.14.pli: Bhavañhi kūṭadanto bahūnaṃ ācariyapācariyo tīṇi māṇavakasatāni mante vāceti, bahū kho pana nānādisā nānājanapadā māṇavakā āgacchanti bhoto kūṭadantassa santike mantatthikā mante adhiyitukāmā …pe…
dn5:6.14.eng: You teach the tutors of many, and teach three hundred young students to recite the hymns. Many students come from various districts and countries for the sake of the hymns, wishing to learn the hymns. …

dn5:6.15.pli: Bhavañhi kūṭadanto jiṇṇo vuddho mahallako addhagato vayoanuppatto.
dn5:6.15.eng: You’re old, elderly and senior, advanced in years, and have reached the final stage of life.

dn5:6.16.pli: Samaṇo gotamo taruṇo ceva taruṇapabbajito ca …pe…
dn5:6.16.eng: The ascetic Gotama is young, and has newly gone forth. …

dn5:6.17.pli: Bhavañhi kūṭadanto rañño māgadhassa seniyassa bimbisārassa sakkato garukato mānito pūjito apacito …pe…
dn5:6.17.eng: You’re honored, respected, revered, venerated, and esteemed by King Bimbisāra of Magadha …

dn5:6.18.pli: Bhavañhi kūṭadanto brāhmaṇassa pokkharasātissa sakkato garukato mānito pūjito apacito …pe…

dn5:6.19.pli: Bhavañhi kūṭadanto khāṇumataṃ ajjhāvasati sattussadaṃ satiṇakaṭṭhodakaṃ sadhaññaṃ rājabhoggaṃ raññā māgadhena seniyena bimbisārena dinnaṃ rājadāyaṃ brahmadeyyaṃ.
dn5:6.19.eng: You live in Khāṇumata, a crown property given by King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha, teeming with living creatures, full of hay, wood, water, and grain, a royal park endowed to a brahmin.

dn5:6.20.pli: Yampi bhavaṃ kūṭadanto khāṇumataṃ ajjhāvasati sattussadaṃ satiṇakaṭṭhodakaṃ sadhaññaṃ rājabhoggaṃ, raññā māgadhena seniyena bimbisārena dinnaṃ rājadāyaṃ brahmadeyyaṃ, imināpaṅgena na arahati bhavaṃ kūṭadanto samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ.
dn5:6.20.eng: For this reason it’s not appropriate for you to go to see the ascetic Gotama;

dn5:6.21.pli: Samaṇo tveva gotamo arahati bhavantaṃ kūṭadantaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamitun”ti.
dn5:6.21.eng: it’s appropriate that he comes to see you.”

dn5:7.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, kūṭadanto brāhmaṇo te brāhmaṇe etadavoca:
dn5:7.1.eng: When they had spoken, Kūṭadanta said to those brahmins:

dn5:7.2.pli: “Tena hi, bho, mamapi suṇātha, yathā mayameva arahāma taṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ,
dn5:7.2.eng: “Well then, gentlemen, listen to why it’s appropriate for me to go to see the ascetic Gotama,

dn5:7.3.pli: na tveva arahati so bhavaṃ gotamo amhākaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ.
dn5:7.3.eng: and it’s not appropriate for him to come to see me.

dn5:7.4.pli: Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo ubhato sujāto mātito ca pitito ca saṃsuddhagahaṇiko yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā akkhitto anupakkuṭṭho jātivādena.
dn5:7.4.eng: He is well born on both his mother’s and father’s side, of pure descent, with irrefutable and impeccable genealogy back to the seventh paternal generation.

dn5:7.5.pli: Yampi, bho, samaṇo gotamo ubhato sujāto mātito ca pitito ca saṃsuddhagahaṇiko yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā akkhitto anupakkuṭṭho jātivādena, imināpaṅgena na arahati so bhavaṃ gotamo amhākaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ.
dn5:7.5.eng: For this reason it’s not appropriate for the ascetic Gotama to come to see me;

dn5:7.6.pli: Atha kho mayameva arahāma taṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ.
dn5:7.6.eng: rather, it’s appropriate for me to go to see him.

dn5:7.7.pli: Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo mahantaṃ ñātisaṅghaṃ ohāya pabbajito …pe…
dn5:7.7.eng: When he went forth he abandoned a large family circle. …

dn5:7.8.pli: Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo pahūtaṃ hiraññasuvaṇṇaṃ ohāya pabbajito bhūmigatañca vehāsaṭṭhaṃ ca …pe…
dn5:7.8.eng: When he went forth he abandoned abundant gold, both coined and uncoined, stored above and below ground. …

dn5:7.9.pli: Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo daharova samāno yuvā susukāḷakeso bhadrena yobbanena samannāgato paṭhamena vayasā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito …pe…
dn5:7.9.eng: He went forth from the lay life to homelessness while still a youth, young, with pristine black hair, blessed with youth, in the prime of life. …

dn5:7.10.pli: Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo akāmakānaṃ mātāpitūnaṃ assumukhānaṃ rudantānaṃ kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito …pe…
dn5:7.10.eng: Though his mother and father wished otherwise, weeping with tearful faces, he shaved off his hair and beard, dressed in ocher robes, and went forth from the lay life to homelessness. …

dn5:7.11.pli: Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo abhirūpo dassanīyo pāsādiko paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgato brahmavaṇṇī brahmavacchasī akhuddāvakāso dassanāya …pe…
dn5:7.11.eng: He is attractive, good-looking, lovely, of surpassing beauty. He has divine looks and lustre, remarkable to behold. …

dn5:7.12.pli: Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo sīlavā ariyasīlī kusalasīlī kusalasīlena samannāgato …pe…
dn5:7.12.eng: He is ethical, possessing ethical conduct that is noble and skillful. …

dn5:7.13.pli: Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo kalyāṇavāco kalyāṇavākkaraṇo poriyā vācāya samannāgato vissaṭṭhāya anelagalāya atthassa viññāpaniyā …pe…
dn5:7.13.eng: He’s a good speaker who enunciates well, with a polished, clear, and articulate voice that expresses the meaning. …

dn5:7.14.pli: Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo bahūnaṃ ācariyapācariyo …pe…

dn5:7.15.pli: Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo khīṇakāmarāgo vigatacāpallo …pe…
dn5:7.15.eng: He has ended sensual desire, and is rid of caprice. …

dn5:7.16.pli: Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo kammavādī kiriyavādī apāpapurekkhāro brahmaññāya pajāya …pe…
dn5:7.16.eng: He teaches the efficacy of deeds and action. He doesn’t wish any harm upon the community of brahmins. …

dn5:7.17.pli: Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo uccā kulā pabbajito asambhinnakhattiyakulā …pe…
dn5:7.17.eng: He went forth from an eminent family of unbroken aristocratic lineage. …

dn5:7.18.pli: Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo aḍḍhā kulā pabbajito mahaddhanā mahābhogā …pe…
dn5:7.18.eng: He went forth from a rich, affluent, and wealthy family. …

dn5:7.19.pli: Samaṇaṃ khalu, bho, gotamaṃ tiroraṭṭhā tirojanapadā pañhaṃ pucchituṃ āgacchanti …pe…
dn5:7.19.eng: People come from distant lands and distant countries to question him. …

dn5:7.20.pli: Samaṇaṃ khalu, bho, gotamaṃ anekāni devatāsahassāni pāṇehi saraṇaṃ gatāni …pe…
dn5:7.20.eng: Many thousands of deities have gone for refuge for life to him. …

dn5:7.21.pli: Samaṇaṃ khalu, bho, gotamaṃ evaṃ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:

dn5:7.22.pli: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’ti …pe…
dn5:7.22.eng: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’ …

dn5:7.23.pli: Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo dvattiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇehi samannāgato …pe…
dn5:7.23.eng: He has the thirty-two marks of a great man. …

dn5:7.24.pli: Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo ehisvāgatavādī sakhilo sammodako abbhākuṭiko uttānamukho pubbabhāsī …pe…
dn5:7.24.eng: He is welcoming, congenial, polite, smiling, open, the first to speak. …

dn5:7.25.pli: Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo catunnaṃ parisānaṃ sakkato garukato mānito pūjito apacito …pe…
dn5:7.25.eng: He’s honored, respected, revered, venerated, and esteemed by the four assemblies. …

dn5:7.26.pli: Samaṇe khalu, bho, gotame bahū devā ca manussā ca abhippasannā …pe…
dn5:7.26.eng: Many gods and humans are devoted to him. …

dn5:7.27.pli: Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo yasmiṃ gāme vā nigame vā paṭivasati na tasmiṃ gāme vā nigame vā amanussā manusse viheṭhenti …pe…
dn5:7.27.eng: While he is residing in a village or town, non-human entities do not harass them. …

dn5:7.28.pli: Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo saṅghī gaṇī gaṇācariyo puthutitthakarānaṃ aggamakkhāyati, yathā kho pana, bho, etesaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ yathā vā tathā vā yaso samudāgacchati, na hevaṃ samaṇassa gotamassa yaso samudāgato.
dn5:7.28.eng: He leads an order and a community, and tutors a community, and is said to be the best of the various religious founders. He didn’t come by his fame in the same ways as those other ascetics and brahmins.

dn5:7.29.pli: Atha kho anuttarāya vijjācaraṇasampadāya samaṇassa gotamassa yaso samudāgato …pe…
dn5:7.29.eng: Rather, he came by his fame due to his supreme knowledge and conduct. …

dn5:7.30.pli: Samaṇaṃ khalu, bho, gotamaṃ rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro saputto sabhariyo sapariso sāmacco pāṇehi saraṇaṃ gato …pe…
dn5:7.30.eng: King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha and his wives and children have gone for refuge for life to the ascetic Gotama. …

dn5:7.31.pli: Samaṇaṃ khalu, bho, gotamaṃ rājā pasenadi kosalo saputto sabhariyo sapariso sāmacco pāṇehi saraṇaṃ gato …pe…
dn5:7.31.eng: King Pasenadi of Kosala and his wives and children have gone for refuge for life to the ascetic Gotama. …

dn5:7.32.pli: Samaṇaṃ khalu, bho, gotamaṃ brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti saputto sabhariyo sapariso sāmacco pāṇehi saraṇaṃ gato …pe…
dn5:7.32.eng: The brahmin Pokkharasāti and his wives and children have gone for refuge for life to the ascetic Gotama. …

dn5:7.33.pli: Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo rañño māgadhassa seniyassa bimbisārassa sakkato garukato mānito pūjito apacito …pe…
dn5:7.33.eng: He’s honored, respected, revered, venerated, and esteemed by King Bimbisāra of Magadha …

dn5:7.34.pli: Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo rañño pasenadissa kosalassa sakkato garukato mānito pūjito apacito …pe…

dn5:7.35.pli: Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo brāhmaṇassa pokkharasātissa sakkato garukato mānito pūjito apacito …pe…

dn5:7.36.pli: Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo khāṇumataṃ anuppatto khāṇumate viharati ambalaṭṭhikāyaṃ.
dn5:7.36.eng: The ascetic Gotama has arrived at Khāṇumata and is staying at Ambalaṭṭhikā.

dn5:7.37.pli: Ye kho pana, bho, keci samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā amhākaṃ gāmakhettaṃ āgacchanti, atithī no te honti.
dn5:7.37.eng: Any ascetic or brahmin who comes to stay in our village district is our guest,

dn5:7.38.pli: Atithī kho panamhehi sakkātabbā garukātabbā mānetabbā pūjetabbā apacetabbā.
dn5:7.38.eng: and should be honored and respected as such.

dn5:7.39.pli: Yampi, bho, samaṇo gotamo khāṇumataṃ anuppatto khāṇumate viharati ambalaṭṭhikāyaṃ, atithimhākaṃ samaṇo gotamo.

dn5:7.40.pli: Atithi kho panamhehi sakkātabbo garukātabbo mānetabbo pūjetabbo apacetabbo.

dn5:7.41.pli: Imināpaṅgena nārahati so bhavaṃ gotamo amhākaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ.
dn5:7.41.eng: For this reason, too, it’s not appropriate for the worthy Gotama to come to see me,

dn5:7.42.pli: Atha kho mayameva arahāma taṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ.
dn5:7.42.eng: rather, it’s appropriate for me to go to see him.

dn5:7.43.pli: Ettake kho ahaṃ, bho, tassa bhoto gotamassa vaṇṇe pariyāpuṇāmi, no ca kho so bhavaṃ gotamo ettakavaṇṇo.
dn5:7.43.eng: This is the extent of the worthy Gotama’s praise that I have memorized. But his praises are not confined to this,

dn5:7.44.eng: for the praise of the worthy Gotama is limitless.”

dn5:7.45.pli: Evaṃ vutte, te brāhmaṇā kūṭadantaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ etadavocuṃ:
dn5:7.45.eng: When he had spoken, those brahmins said to him,

dn5:7.46.pli: “yathā kho bhavaṃ kūṭadanto samaṇassa gotamassa vaṇṇe bhāsati, ito cepi so bhavaṃ gotamo yojanasate viharati, alameva saddhena kulaputtena dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ api puṭosenā”ti.
dn5:7.46.eng: “According to Kūṭadanta’s praises, if the worthy Gotama were staying within a hundred leagues, it’d be worthwhile for a faithful gentleman to go to see him, even if he had to carry his own provisions in a knapsack.”

dn5:7.47.pli: “Tena hi, bho, sabbeva mayaṃ samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamissāmā”ti.
dn5:7.47.eng: “Well then, gentlemen, let’s all go to see the ascetic Gotama.”

dn5:8.0.eng: 4. The Story of King Mahāvijita’s Sacrifice

dn5:8.1.pli: Atha kho kūṭadanto brāhmaṇo mahatā brāhmaṇagaṇena saddhiṃ yena ambalaṭṭhikā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
dn5:8.1.eng: Then Kūṭadanta together with a large group of brahmins went to see the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him.

dn5:8.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
dn5:8.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side.

dn5:8.3.pli: Khāṇumatakāpi kho brāhmaṇagahapatikā appekacce bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu; appekacce bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodiṃsu, sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu; appekacce yena bhagavā tenañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu; appekacce nāmagottaṃ sāvetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu; appekacce tuṇhībhūtā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu.
dn5:8.3.eng: Before sitting down to one side, some of the brahmins and householders of Khāṇumata bowed, some exchanged greetings and polite conversation, some held up their joined palms toward the Buddha, some announced their name and clan, while some kept silent.

dn5:9.1.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho kūṭadanto brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:

dn5:9.3.eng: you know how to accomplish the sacrifice with three modes and sixteen accessories.

dn5:9.4.pli: Na kho panāhaṃ jānāmi tividhaṃ yaññasampadaṃ soḷasaparikkhāraṃ.

dn5:9.5.eng: but I wish to perform a great sacrifice.

dn5:9.6.pli: Sādhu me bhavaṃ gotamo tividhaṃ yaññasampadaṃ soḷasaparikkhāraṃ desetū”ti.
dn5:9.6.eng: Please teach me how to accomplish the sacrifice with three modes and sixteen accessories.”

dn5:9.7.pli: “Tena hi, brāhmaṇa, suṇāhi sādhukaṃ manasikarohi, bhāsissāmī”ti.
dn5:9.7.eng: “Well then, brahmin, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
dn5:9.7.comm: Kūṭadanta’s proposal that the Buddha advise him on the sacrifice of 700 animals is outrageous. Nonetheless, the Buddha responds politely since Kūṭadanta is being polite. While it is tempting to see the sacrifice of animals by supposedly virtuous priests as sheer hypocrisy, the fact of sacrifice remains one of the most widespread and mysterious of human religious practices. In an empathetic work that addresses this squarely, Roberto Calasso’s Ardor sees the vast complex of Vedic ritual and theory as making plain the fact of killing so that the guilt may be contained, in contrast with our modern culture of killing on an industrial scale while hiding it out of sight.

dn5:9.8.pli: “Evaṃ, bho”ti kho kūṭadanto brāhmaṇo bhagavato paccassosi.

dn5:10.1.pli: “bhūtapubbaṃ, brāhmaṇa, rājā mahāvijito nāma ahosi aḍḍho mahaddhano mahābhogo pahūtajātarūparajato pahūtavittūpakaraṇo pahūtadhanadhañño paripuṇṇakosakoṭṭhāgāro.
dn5:10.1.eng: “Once upon a time, brahmin, there was a king named Mahāvijita. He was rich, affluent, and wealthy, with lots of gold and silver, lots of property and assets, lots of money and grain, and a full treasury and storehouses.
dn5:10.1.comm: Mahāvijita means “Great Dominion”. He seems to be only known from this story. The idiom bhūtapubbaṁ (literally “so it was in the past”) introduces legendary narratives of usually dubious historicity, like the English idiom “once upon a time”.

dn5:10.2.pli: Atha kho, brāhmaṇa, rañño mahāvijitassa rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:
dn5:10.2.eng: Then as King Mahāvijita was in private retreat this thought came to his mind:
dn5:10.2.comm: In the Pali, meaningful thoughts often occur to people when withdrawn in seclusion. This doesn’t necessary mean they were in formal meditation.

dn5:10.3.pli: ‘adhigatā kho me vipulā mānusakā bhogā, mahantaṃ pathavimaṇḍalaṃ abhivijiya ajjhāvasāmi, yannūnāhaṃ mahāyaññaṃ yajeyyaṃ, yaṃ mama assa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā’ti.
dn5:10.3.eng: ‘I have achieved human wealth, and reign after conquering this vast territory. Why don’t I hold a large sacrifice? That will be for my lasting welfare and happiness.’
dn5:10.3.comm: The great sacrifices, especially the horse sacrifice, ensured royal authority. Their very scale and wastefulness showed off the wealth of the king.

dn5:10.4.pli: Atha kho, brāhmaṇa, rājā mahāvijito purohitaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ āmantetvā etadavoca:
dn5:10.4.eng: Then he summoned the brahmin high priest and said to him:
dn5:10.4.comm: “High priest” is purohita. He was a family chaplain advising and consecrating the royal family. The closeness of the relationship is shown by the fact that the royal family would take the lineage name of the purohita.

dn5:10.5.pli: ‘idha mayhaṃ, brāhmaṇa, rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:
dn5:10.5.eng: ‘Just now, brahmin, as I was in private retreat this thought came to mind,

dn5:10.6.pli: “adhigatā kho me vipulā mānusakā bhogā, mahantaṃ pathavimaṇḍalaṃ abhivijiya ajjhāvasāmi. Yannūnāhaṃ mahāyaññaṃ yajeyyaṃ yaṃ mama assa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā”ti.
dn5:10.6.eng: “I have achieved human wealth, and reign after conquering this vast territory. Why don’t I perform a great sacrifice? That will be for my lasting welfare and happiness.”

dn5:10.7.eng: Brahmin, I wish to perform a great sacrifice.

dn5:10.8.pli: Anusāsatu maṃ bhavaṃ yaṃ mama assa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā’ti.
dn5:10.8.eng: Please instruct me. It will be for my lasting welfare and happiness.’

dn5:11.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, brāhmaṇa, purohito brāhmaṇo rājānaṃ mahāvijitaṃ etadavoca:
dn5:11.1.eng: When he had spoken, the brahmin high priest said to him:

dn5:11.2.pli: ‘bhoto kho rañño janapado sakaṇṭako sauppīḷo, gāmaghātāpi dissanti, nigamaghātāpi dissanti, nagaraghātāpi dissanti, panthaduhanāpi dissanti.
dn5:11.2.eng: ‘Sir, the king’s realm is harried and oppressed. Raiding of villages, towns, and cities has been seen, and infesting of highways.
dn5:11.2.comm: Then, as today, government policy was driven by the perception of rising crime rate. This whole passage is one of the Buddha’s most important statements on public policy. It is expressed through storytelling, giving a good example of how myths were invoked—and subverted—as rationales for current policy.

dn5:11.3.pli: Bhavaṃ kho pana rājā evaṃ sakaṇṭake janapade sauppīḷe balimuddhareyya, akiccakārī assa tena bhavaṃ rājā.
dn5:11.3.eng: But if the king were to extract more taxes while his realm is thus harried and oppressed, he would not be doing his duty.
dn5:11.3.comm: “Taxes” is bali. He would have had to press his people for the extra funds to hold the sacrifice.

dn5:11.4.pli: Siyā kho pana bhoto rañño evamassa:

dn5:11.5.pli: “ahametaṃ dassukhīlaṃ vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā pabbājanāya vā samūhanissāmī”ti, na kho panetassa dassukhīlassa evaṃ sammā samugghāto hoti.
dn5:11.5.eng: “I’ll eradicate this plague of savages by execution or imprisonment or confiscation or condemnation or banishment!” But that’s not the right way to eradicate this plague of savages.
dn5:11.5.comm: “Plague of savages” (dassukhīla) is the only occurrence of Sanskrit dasyu in early Pali. The dasyu were inveterate foes of the Aryans in the Vedic period. Bereft of civilizing rites, scriptures, and observances, they were no children of Manu (Rig Veda 10.22.8). Their wiles (māyā) made them a potent threat (Rig Veda 4.16.9, 8.14.14, 10.73.5). Indra was invoked to ensure their destruction (Rig Veda passim; Atharva Veda 2.14.5, 4.32.3, 20.21.4, 20.37.5, 20.42.2). Legend has it that Agni and Soma first supported the dasyu before being won over by Indra (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 1.6.3.13; see also 6.4.2.4). By the time of the Buddha the dasyu have vanished except as a legendary foe of the past. Where the Brahmanical texts advocate the pitiless destruction of the dasyu, the brahmin high priest in the Buddhist text advocates an inclusive policy of social welfare.

dn5:11.6.pli: Ye te hatāvasesakā bhavissanti, te pacchā rañño janapadaṃ viheṭhessanti.
dn5:11.6.eng: Those who remain after the killing will return to harass the king’s realm.
dn5:11.6.comm: The priest knows that the king will respond better to a pragmatic argument than a moral one.

dn5:11.7.pli: Api ca kho idaṃ saṃvidhānaṃ āgamma evametassa dassukhīlassa sammā samugghāto hoti.
dn5:11.7.eng: Rather, here is a plan, relying on which the plague of savages will be properly uprooted.
dn5:11.7.comm: Effective social policy requires a forward-thinking plan, not just reacting to grievances.

dn5:11.8.pli: Tena hi bhavaṃ rājā ye bhoto rañño janapade ussahanti kasigorakkhe, tesaṃ bhavaṃ rājā bījabhattaṃ anuppadetu.
dn5:11.8.eng: So let the king provide seed and fodder for those in the realm who work in growing crops and raising cattle.
dn5:11.8.comm: The king should spend his own resources to support his citizens in the various occupations.

dn5:11.9.pli: Ye bhoto rañño janapade ussahanti vāṇijjāya, tesaṃ bhavaṃ rājā pābhataṃ anuppadetu.
dn5:11.9.eng: Let the king provide funding for those who work in trade.

dn5:11.10.pli: Ye bhoto rañño janapade ussahanti rājaporise, tesaṃ bhavaṃ rājā bhattavetanaṃ pakappetu.
dn5:11.10.eng: Let the king guarantee food and wages for those in government service.

dn5:11.11.pli: Te ca manussā sakammapasutā rañño janapadaṃ na viheṭhessanti;
dn5:11.11.eng: Then the people, occupied with their own work, will not harass the realm.
dn5:11.11.comm: Here the priest identifies a fundamental cause of social unrest and disorder.

dn5:11.12.eng: The king’s revenues will be great.
dn5:11.12.comm: The king spends out of pocket, but the economy flourishes, so tax revenues increase even though he has not raised taxes. This is the essence of Keynesian economic theory.

dn5:11.13.pli: Khemaṭṭhitā janapadā akaṇṭakā anuppīḷā. Manussā mudā modamānā ure putte naccentā apārutagharā maññe viharissantī’ti.
dn5:11.13.eng: When the country is secured as a sanctuary, free of being harried and oppressed, the happy people, with joy in their hearts, dancing with children at their breast, will dwell as if their houses were wide open.’
dn5:11.13.comm: Khema means a place of safety and sanctuary, where both humans and animals have no fear.

dn5:11.14.pli: ‘Evaṃ, bho’ti kho, brāhmaṇa, rājā mahāvijito purohitassa brāhmaṇassa paṭissutvā ye rañño janapade ussahiṃsu kasigorakkhe, tesaṃ rājā mahāvijito bījabhattaṃ anuppadāsi.
dn5:11.14.eng: The king agreed with the high priest’s advice and followed his recommendation.
dn5:11.14.comm: A good leader listens to advice.

dn5:11.15.pli: Ye ca rañño janapade ussahiṃsu vāṇijjāya, tesaṃ rājā mahāvijito pābhataṃ anuppadāsi.

dn5:11.16.pli: Ye ca rañño janapade ussahiṃsu rājaporise, tesaṃ rājā mahāvijito bhattavetanaṃ pakappesi.

dn5:11.17.pli: Te ca manussā sakammapasutā rañño janapadaṃ na viheṭhiṃsu, mahā ca rañño rāsiko ahosi.

dn5:11.18.pli: Khemaṭṭhitā janapadā akaṇṭakā anuppīḷā manussā mudā modamānā ure putte naccentā apārutagharā maññe vihariṃsu.

dn5:11.19.pli: Atha kho, brāhmaṇa, rājā mahāvijito purohitaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ āmantetvā etadavoca:
dn5:11.19.eng: Then the king summoned the brahmin high priest and said to him:

dn5:11.20.pli: ‘samūhato kho me bhoto dassukhīlo, bhoto saṃvidhānaṃ āgamma mahā ca me rāsiko.
dn5:11.20.eng: ‘I have eradicated the plague of savages. And relying on your plan my revenue is now great.

dn5:11.21.pli: Khemaṭṭhitā janapadā akaṇṭakā anuppīḷā manussā mudā modamānā ure putte naccentā apārutagharā maññe viharanti.
dn5:11.21.eng: Since the country is secured as a sanctuary, free of being harried and oppressed, the happy people, with joy in their hearts, dancing with children at their breast, dwell as if their houses were wide open.

dn5:11.22.eng: Brahmin, I wish to perform a great sacrifice.

dn5:11.23.pli: Anusāsatu maṃ bhavaṃ yaṃ mama assa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā’ti.
dn5:11.23.eng: Please instruct me. It will be for my lasting welfare and happiness.’

dn5:12.1.pli: Tena hi bhavaṃ rājā ye bhoto rañño janapade khattiyā ānuyantā negamā ceva jānapadā ca te bhavaṃ rājā āmantayataṃ: ‘icchāmahaṃ, bho, mahāyaññaṃ yajituṃ, anujānantu me bhavanto yaṃ mama assa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā’ti. Ye bhoto rañño janapade amaccā pārisajjā negamā ceva jānapadā ca …pe… brāhmaṇamahāsālā negamā ceva jānapadā ca …pe… gahapatinecayikā negamā ceva jānapadā ca, te bhavaṃ rājā āmantayataṃ:
dn5:12.1.eng: ‘In that case, let the king announce this throughout the realm to the aristocrat vassals of both town and country; the ministers and councillors of both town and country; the well-to-do brahmins of both town and country; and the well-off householders of both town and country.
dn5:12.1.comm: Here the phrase “of both town and country” qualifies each group. At AN 4.70:1.3, however, “brahmins and householders” and “people of town and country” are separate groups of people. Elsewhere the context does not always decide between these two possibilities. Generally the idiom aims at inclusivity, as opposed to here where the king is consulting the rich and powerful, so I treat them as two separate groups, thus including the common folk.

dn5:12.2.pli: ‘icchāmahaṃ, bho, mahāyaññaṃ yajituṃ, anujānantu me bhavanto yaṃ mama assa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā’ti.
dn5:12.2.eng: “I wish to perform a great sacrifice. Please grant your approval, good fellows; it will be for my lasting welfare and happiness.”

dn5:12.3.pli: ‘Evaṃ, bho’ti kho, brāhmaṇa, rājā mahāvijito purohitassa brāhmaṇassa paṭissutvā ye rañño janapade khattiyā ānuyantā negamā ceva jānapadā ca, te rājā mahāvijito āmantesi:
dn5:12.3.eng: The king agreed with the high priest’s advice and followed his recommendation.

dn5:12.4.pli: ‘icchāmahaṃ, bho, mahāyaññaṃ yajituṃ, anujānantu me bhavanto yaṃ mama assa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā’ti.
dn5:12.4.eng: And all of the people who were thus informed responded by saying:

dn5:12.5.eng: ‘May the king perform a sacrifice! It is time for a sacrifice, great king.’

dn5:12.6.pli: Ye rañño janapade amaccā pārisajjā negamā ceva jānapadā ca …pe… brāhmaṇamahāsālā negamā ceva jānapadā ca …pe… gahapatinecayikā negamā ceva jānapadā ca, te rājā mahāvijito āmantesi:

dn5:12.7.pli: ‘icchāmahaṃ, bho, mahāyaññaṃ yajituṃ. Anujānantu me bhavanto yaṃ mama assa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā’ti.

dn5:12.9.pli: Itime cattāro anumatipakkhā tasseva yaññassa parikkhārā bhavanti.
dn5:12.9.eng: And so these four consenting factions became accessories to the sacrifice.
dn5:12.9.comm: “Consenting factions” is anumatipakkhā. The king governs with the consent of his people, although only the landowning classes are considered.

dn5:13.1.comm: Royal authority is not based just on birth, conquest, ritual, or power, but on quality of character.

dn5:13.2.pli: ubhato sujāto mātito ca pitito ca saṃsuddhagahaṇiko yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā akkhitto anupakkuṭṭho jātivādena;
dn5:13.2.eng: He was well born on both his mother’s and father’s side, of pure descent, with irrefutable and impeccable genealogy back to the seventh paternal generation.

dn5:13.3.pli: abhirūpo dassanīyo pāsādiko paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgato brahmavaṇṇī brahmavacchasī akhuddāvakāso dassanāya;
dn5:13.3.eng: He was attractive, good-looking, lovely, of surpassing beauty. He had divine looks and lustre, remarkable to behold.

dn5:13.4.pli: aḍḍho mahaddhano mahābhogo pahūtajātarūparajato pahūtavittūpakaraṇo pahūtadhanadhañño paripuṇṇakosakoṭṭhāgāro;
dn5:13.4.eng: He was rich, affluent, and wealthy, with lots of gold and silver, lots of property and assets, lots of money and grain, and a full treasury and storehouses.

dn5:13.5.pli: balavā caturaṅginiyā senāya samannāgato assavāya ovādapaṭikarāya sahati maññe paccatthike yasasā;
dn5:13.5.eng: He was powerful, having an army of four divisions that was obedient and carried out instructions. He’d probably prevail over his enemies just with his reputation.
dn5:13.5.comm: Read sahati (“prevails”) over the several variants.

dn5:13.6.pli: saddho dāyako dānapati anāvaṭadvāro samaṇabrāhmaṇakapaṇaddhikavaṇibbakayācakānaṃ opānabhūto puññāni karoti;
dn5:13.6.eng: He was faithful, generous, a donor, his door always open. He was a well-spring of support, making merit with ascetics and brahmins, for paupers, vagrants, supplicants, and beggars.

dn5:13.7.pli: bahussuto tassa tassa sutajātassa, tassa tasseva kho pana bhāsitassa atthaṃ jānāti:
dn5:13.7.eng: He was very learned in diverse fields of learning. He understood the meaning of diverse statements, saying:
dn5:13.7.comm: Showing the importance of comprehension over blind adherence to tradition.

dn5:13.8.pli: ‘ayaṃ imassa bhāsitassa attho ayaṃ imassa bhāsitassa attho’ti;
dn5:13.8.eng: ‘This is what that statement means; that is what this statement means.’

dn5:13.9.pli: paṇḍito, viyatto, medhāvī, paṭibalo, atītānāgatapaccuppanne atthe cintetuṃ.
dn5:13.9.eng: He was astute, competent, and intelligent, able to think issues through as they bear upon the past, future, and present.
dn5:13.9.comm: Meditators focus on the present, but that does not mean they cannot think about the past or future; it just means they are not trapped in useless thoughts.

dn5:13.10.eng: These are the eight factors that King Mahāvijita possessed.

dn5:13.11.pli: Iti imānipi aṭṭhaṅgāni tasseva yaññassa parikkhārā bhavanti.
dn5:13.11.eng: And so these eight factors also became accessories to the sacrifice.

dn5:14.1.eng: And the brahmin high priest had four factors.
dn5:14.1.comm: These are four of the five qualities that Soṇadaṇḍa identifies as the qualities of a brahmin at DN 4:13.2. Missing is appearance, which is the first factor that Soṇadaṇḍa admits is unnecessary.

dn5:14.2.pli: ubhato sujāto mātito ca pitito ca saṃsuddhagahaṇiko yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā akkhitto anupakkuṭṭho jātivādena;
dn5:14.2.eng: He was well born on both his mother’s and father’s side, of pure descent, with irrefutable and impeccable genealogy back to the seventh paternal generation.

dn5:14.3.pli: ajjhāyako mantadharo tiṇṇaṃ vedānaṃ pāragū sanighaṇḍukeṭubhānaṃ sākkharappabhedānaṃ itihāsapañcamānaṃ padako veyyākaraṇo lokāyatamahāpurisalakkhaṇesu anavayo;
dn5:14.3.eng: He recited and remembered the hymns, and had mastered the three Vedas, together with their vocabularies and ritual performance, their phonology and word classification, and the testaments as fifth. He knew them word-by-word, and their grammar. He was well versed in cosmology and the marks of a great man.

dn5:14.4.eng: He was ethical, mature in ethical conduct.

dn5:14.5.pli: paṇḍito viyatto medhāvī paṭhamo vā dutiyo vā sujaṃ paggaṇhantānaṃ.
dn5:14.5.eng: He was astute and clever, being the first or second to hold the sacrificial ladle.

dn5:14.6.eng: These are the four factors that the brahmin high priest possessed.

dn5:14.7.pli: Iti imānipi cattāri aṅgāni tasseva yaññassa parikkhārā bhavanti.
dn5:14.7.eng: And so these four factors also became accessories to the sacrifice.

dn5:15.1.pli: Atha kho, brāhmaṇa, purohito brāhmaṇo rañño mahāvijitassa pubbeva yaññā tisso vidhā desesi.
dn5:15.1.eng: Next, before the sacrifice, the brahmin high priest taught the three modes to the king.

dn5:15.2.pli: Siyā kho pana bhoto rañño mahāyaññaṃ yiṭṭhukāmassa kocideva vippaṭisāro:
dn5:15.2.eng: ‘Now, though the king wants to perform a great sacrifice, he might have certain regrets, thinking:

dn5:15.3.pli: ‘“mahā vata me bhogakkhandho vigacchissatī”ti, so bhotā raññā vippaṭisāro na karaṇīyo.
dn5:15.3.eng: “I shall lose a great fortune,” or
dn5:15.3.comm: Compare the three factors of a donor’s mind-state at AN 6.37:2.4.

dn5:15.4.pli: Siyā kho pana bhoto rañño mahāyaññaṃ yajamānassa kocideva vippaṭisāro:

dn5:15.5.pli: “mahā vata me bhogakkhandho vigacchatī”ti, so bhotā raññā vippaṭisāro na karaṇīyo.
dn5:15.5.eng: “I am losing a great fortune,” or

dn5:15.6.pli: Siyā kho pana bhoto rañño mahāyaññaṃ yiṭṭhassa kocideva vippaṭisāro:

dn5:15.7.pli: “mahā vata me bhogakkhandho vigato”ti, so bhotā raññā vippaṭisāro na karaṇīyo’ti.
dn5:15.7.eng: “I have lost a great fortune.” But the king should not harbor such regrets.’

dn5:15.8.pli: Imā kho, brāhmaṇa, purohito brāhmaṇo rañño mahāvijitassa pubbeva yaññā tisso vidhā desesi.
dn5:15.8.eng: These are the three modes that the brahmin high priest taught to the king before the sacrifice.

dn5:16.1.pli: Atha kho, brāhmaṇa, purohito brāhmaṇo rañño mahāvijitassa pubbeva yaññā dasahākārehi paṭiggāhakesu vippaṭisāraṃ paṭivinesi.
dn5:16.1.eng: Next, before the sacrifice, the brahmin high priest dispelled the king’s regret regarding the recipients in ten respects:
dn5:16.1.comm: What a recipient does with a gift is beyond the donor’s control.

dn5:16.2.pli: ‘Āgamissanti kho bhoto yaññaṃ pāṇātipātinopi pāṇātipātā paṭiviratāpi.
dn5:16.2.eng: ‘There will come to the sacrifice those who kill living creatures and those who refrain from killing living creatures.

dn5:16.3.eng: As to those who kill living creatures, the outcome of that is theirs alone.

dn5:16.4.pli: Ye tattha pāṇātipātā paṭiviratā, te ārabbha yajataṃ bhavaṃ, sajjataṃ bhavaṃ, modataṃ bhavaṃ, cittameva bhavaṃ antaraṃ pasādetu.
dn5:16.4.eng: But as to those who refrain from killing living creatures, it is for their sakes that the king should sacrifice, relinquish, rejoice, and gain confidence in his heart.
dn5:16.4.comm: PTS edition acknowledges sajjata only as a variant reading, but it is in the commentary, so should be accepted in the text. It is from √sajj (relinquish).

dn5:16.5.pli: Āgamissanti kho bhoto yaññaṃ adinnādāyinopi adinnādānā paṭiviratāpi …pe…
dn5:16.5.eng: There will come to the sacrifice those who steal …

dn5:16.13.eng: have wrong view and those who have right view.

dn5:16.14.eng: As to those who have wrong view, the outcome of that is theirs alone.

dn5:16.15.pli: Ye tattha sammādiṭṭhikā, te ārabbha yajataṃ bhavaṃ, sajjataṃ bhavaṃ, modataṃ bhavaṃ, cittameva bhavaṃ antaraṃ pasādetū’ti.
dn5:16.15.eng: But as to those who have right view, it is for their sakes that the king should sacrifice, relinquish, rejoice, and gain confidence in his heart.’

dn5:16.16.pli: Imehi kho, brāhmaṇa, purohito brāhmaṇo rañño mahāvijitassa pubbeva yaññā dasahākārehi paṭiggāhakesu vippaṭisāraṃ paṭivinesi.
dn5:16.16.eng: These are the ten respects in which the high priest dispelled the king’s regret regarding the recipients before the sacrifice.

dn5:17.1.pli: Atha kho, brāhmaṇa, purohito brāhmaṇo rañño mahāvijitassa mahāyaññaṃ yajamānassa soḷasahākārehi cittaṃ sandassesi samādapesi samuttejesi sampahaṃsesi
dn5:17.1.eng: Next, while the king was performing the great sacrifice, the brahmin high priest educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired the king’s mind in sixteen respects:

dn5:17.2.pli: siyā kho pana bhoto rañño mahāyaññaṃ yajamānassa kocideva vattā:
dn5:17.2.eng: ‘Now, while the king is performing the great sacrifice, someone might say,

dn5:17.3.pli: ‘rājā kho mahāvijito mahāyaññaṃ yajati, no ca kho tassa āmantitā khattiyā ānuyantā negamā ceva jānapadā ca;
dn5:17.3.eng: “King Mahāvijita performs a great sacrifice, but he did not announce it to the aristocrat vassals of town and country.
dn5:17.3.comm: Another lesson in leadership: the importance of communication.

dn5:17.4.pli: atha ca pana bhavaṃ rājā evarūpaṃ mahāyaññaṃ yajatī’ti.
dn5:17.4.eng: That’s the kind of great sacrifice that this king performs.”

dn5:17.5.pli: Evampi bhoto rañño vattā dhammato natthi.
dn5:17.5.eng: Those who speak against the king in this way have no legitimacy.

dn5:17.6.pli: Bhotā kho pana raññā āmantitā khattiyā ānuyantā negamā ceva jānapadā ca.
dn5:17.6.eng: For the king did indeed announce it to the aristocrat vassals of town and country.

dn5:17.7.pli: Imināpetaṃ bhavaṃ rājā jānātu, yajataṃ bhavaṃ, sajjataṃ bhavaṃ, modataṃ bhavaṃ, cittameva bhavaṃ antaraṃ pasādetu.
dn5:17.7.eng: Let the king know this as a reason to sacrifice, relinquish, rejoice, and gain confidence in his heart.

dn5:17.8.pli: Siyā kho pana bhoto rañño mahāyaññaṃ yajamānassa kocideva vattā:
dn5:17.8.eng: While the king is performing the great sacrifice, someone might say,

dn5:17.9.pli: ‘rājā kho mahāvijito mahāyaññaṃ yajati, no ca kho tassa āmantitā amaccā pārisajjā negamā ceva jānapadā ca …pe… brāhmaṇamahāsālā negamā ceva jānapadā ca …pe… gahapatinecayikā negamā ceva jānapadā ca, atha ca pana bhavaṃ rājā evarūpaṃ mahāyaññaṃ yajatī’ti.
dn5:17.9.eng: “King Mahāvijita performs a great sacrifice, but he did not announce it to the aristocrat vassals; the ministers and councillors; the well-to-do brahmins; and the well-off householders. That’s the kind of great sacrifice that this king performs.”

dn5:17.10.pli: Evampi bhoto rañño vattā dhammato natthi.
dn5:17.10.eng: Those who speak against the king in this way have no legitimacy.

dn5:17.11.pli: Bhotā kho pana raññā āmantitā gahapatinecayikā negamā ceva jānapadā ca.
dn5:17.11.eng: For the king did indeed announce it to all these people.
dn5:17.11.comm: Due to abbreviation, the text only mentions householders here, but clearly all are intended.

dn5:17.12.pli: Imināpetaṃ bhavaṃ rājā jānātu, yajataṃ bhavaṃ, sajjataṃ bhavaṃ, modataṃ bhavaṃ, cittameva bhavaṃ antaraṃ pasādetu.
dn5:17.12.eng: Let the king know this too as a reason to sacrifice, relinquish, rejoice, and gain confidence in his heart.

dn5:17.13.pli: Siyā kho pana bhoto rañño mahāyaññaṃ yajamānassa kocideva vattā:
dn5:17.13.eng: While the king is performing the great sacrifice, someone might say

dn5:17.14.pli: ‘rājā kho mahāvijito mahāyaññaṃ yajati, no ca kho ubhato sujāto mātito ca pitito ca saṃsuddhagahaṇiko yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā akkhitto anupakkuṭṭho jātivādena, atha ca pana bhavaṃ rājā evarūpaṃ mahāyaññaṃ yajatī’ti.
dn5:17.14.eng: that he does not possess the eight factors.

dn5:17.15.pli: Evampi bhoto rañño vattā dhammato natthi.

dn5:17.16.pli: Bhavaṃ kho pana rājā ubhato sujāto mātito ca pitito ca saṃsuddhagahaṇiko yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā akkhitto anupakkuṭṭho jātivādena.

dn5:17.17.pli: Imināpetaṃ bhavaṃ rājā jānātu, yajataṃ bhavaṃ, sajjataṃ bhavaṃ, modataṃ bhavaṃ, cittameva bhavaṃ antaraṃ pasādetu.

dn5:17.18.pli: Siyā kho pana bhoto rañño mahāyaññaṃ yajamānassa kocideva vattā:

dn5:17.19.pli: ‘rājā kho mahāvijito mahāyaññaṃ yajati no ca kho abhirūpo dassanīyo pāsādiko paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgato brahmavaṇṇī brahmavacchasī akhuddāvakāso dassanāya …pe…

dn5:17.20.pli: no ca kho aḍḍho mahaddhano mahābhogo pahūtajātarūparajato pahūtavittūpakaraṇo pahūtadhanadhañño paripuṇṇakosakoṭṭhāgāro …pe…

dn5:17.21.pli: no ca kho balavā caturaṅginiyā senāya samannāgato assavāya ovādapaṭikarāya sahati maññe paccatthike yasasā …pe…

dn5:17.22.pli: no ca kho saddho dāyako dānapati anāvaṭadvāro samaṇabrāhmaṇakapaṇaddhikavaṇibbakayācakānaṃ opānabhūto puññāni karoti …pe…

dn5:17.23.pli: no ca kho bahussuto tassa tassa sutajātassa …pe…

dn5:17.24.pli: no ca kho tassa tasseva kho pana bhāsitassa atthaṃ jānāti:

dn5:17.25.pli: “ayaṃ imassa bhāsitassa attho, ayaṃ imassa bhāsitassa attho”ti …pe…

dn5:17.26.pli: no ca kho paṇḍito viyatto medhāvī paṭibalo atītānāgatapaccuppanne atthe cintetuṃ, atha ca pana bhavaṃ rājā evarūpaṃ mahāyaññaṃ yajatī’ti.

dn5:17.27.pli: Evampi bhoto rañño vattā dhammato natthi.
dn5:17.27.eng: Those who speak against the king in this way have no legitimacy.

dn5:17.28.pli: Bhavaṃ kho pana rājā paṇḍito viyatto medhāvī paṭibalo atītānāgatapaccuppanne atthe cintetuṃ.
dn5:17.28.eng: For the king does indeed possess the eight factors.

dn5:17.29.pli: Imināpetaṃ bhavaṃ rājā jānātu, yajataṃ bhavaṃ, sajjataṃ bhavaṃ, modataṃ bhavaṃ, cittameva bhavaṃ antaraṃ pasādetu.
dn5:17.29.eng: Let the king know this too as a reason to sacrifice, relinquish, rejoice, and gain confidence in his heart.

dn5:17.30.pli: Siyā kho pana bhoto rañño mahāyaññaṃ yajamānassa kocideva vattā:
dn5:17.30.eng: While the king is performing the great sacrifice, someone might say

dn5:17.31.eng: that the high priest does not possess the four factors.

dn5:17.32.pli: No ca khvassa purohito brāhmaṇo ubhato sujāto mātito ca pitito ca saṃsuddhagahaṇiko yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā akkhitto anupakkuṭṭho jātivādena;

dn5:17.33.pli: atha ca pana bhavaṃ rājā evarūpaṃ mahāyaññaṃ yajatī’ti.

dn5:17.34.pli: Evampi bhoto rañño vattā dhammato natthi.

dn5:17.35.pli: Bhoto kho pana rañño purohito brāhmaṇo ubhato sujāto mātito ca pitito ca saṃsuddhagahaṇiko yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā akkhitto anupakkuṭṭho jātivādena.

dn5:17.36.pli: Imināpetaṃ bhavaṃ rājā jānātu, yajataṃ bhavaṃ, sajjataṃ bhavaṃ, modataṃ bhavaṃ, cittameva bhavaṃ antaraṃ pasādetu.

dn5:17.37.pli: Siyā kho pana bhoto rañño mahāyaññaṃ yajamānassa kocideva vattā:

dn5:17.39.pli: No ca khvassa purohito brāhmaṇo ajjhāyako mantadharo tiṇṇaṃ vedānaṃ pāragū sanighaṇḍukeṭubhānaṃ sākkharappabhedānaṃ itihāsapañcamānaṃ padako veyyākaraṇo lokāyatamahāpurisalakkhaṇesu anavayo …pe…

dn5:17.40.pli: no ca khvassa purohito brāhmaṇo sīlavā vuddhasīlī vuddhasīlena samannāgato …pe…

dn5:17.41.pli: no ca khvassa purohito brāhmaṇo paṇḍito viyatto medhāvī paṭhamo vā dutiyo vā sujaṃ paggaṇhantānaṃ, atha ca pana bhavaṃ rājā evarūpaṃ mahāyaññaṃ yajatī’ti.

dn5:17.42.pli: Evampi bhoto rañño vattā dhammato natthi.
dn5:17.42.eng: Those who speak against the king in this way have no legitimacy.

dn5:17.43.pli: Bhoto kho pana rañño purohito brāhmaṇo paṇḍito viyatto medhāvī paṭhamo vā dutiyo vā sujaṃ paggaṇhantānaṃ.
dn5:17.43.eng: For the high priest does indeed possess the four factors.

dn5:17.44.pli: Imināpetaṃ bhavaṃ rājā jānātu, yajataṃ bhavaṃ, sajjataṃ bhavaṃ, modataṃ bhavaṃ, cittameva bhavaṃ antaraṃ pasādetūti.
dn5:17.44.eng: Let the king know this too as a reason to sacrifice, relinquish, rejoice, and gain confidence in his heart.’

dn5:17.45.pli: Imehi kho, brāhmaṇa, purohito brāhmaṇo rañño mahāvijitassa mahāyaññaṃ yajamānassa soḷasahi ākārehi cittaṃ sandassesi samādapesi samuttejesi sampahaṃsesi.
dn5:17.45.eng: These are the sixteen respects in which the high priest educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired the king’s mind while he was performing the sacrifice.

dn5:18.1.pli: Tasmiṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, yaññe neva gāvo haññiṃsu, na ajeḷakā haññiṃsu, na kukkuṭasūkarā haññiṃsu, na vividhā pāṇā saṅghātaṃ āpajjiṃsu, na rukkhā chijjiṃsu yūpatthāya, na dabbhā lūyiṃsu barihisatthāya.
dn5:18.1.eng: And brahmin, in that sacrifice no cattle were killed, no goats or sheep were killed, and no chickens or pigs were killed. There was no slaughter of various kinds of creatures. No trees were felled for the sacrificial post. No grass was reaped to strew over the place of sacrifice.

dn5:18.2.pli: Yepissa ahesuṃ dāsāti vā pessāti vā kammakarāti vā, tepi na daṇḍatajjitā na bhayatajjitā na assumukhā rudamānā parikammāni akaṃsu.
dn5:18.2.eng: No bondservants, servants, or workers did their jobs under threat of punishment and danger, weeping with tearful faces.

dn5:18.3.pli: Atha kho ye icchiṃsu, te akaṃsu, ye na icchiṃsu, na te akaṃsu;
dn5:18.3.eng: Those who wished to work did so, while those who did not wish to did not.
dn5:18.3.comm: A leader gets results through inspiration, not fear.

dn5:18.4.pli: yaṃ icchiṃsu, taṃ akaṃsu, yaṃ na icchiṃsu, na taṃ akaṃsu.
dn5:18.4.eng: They did the work they wanted to, and did not do what they didn’t want to.

dn5:18.5.eng: The sacrifice was completed with just ghee, oil, butter, curds, honey, and molasses.
dn5:18.5.comm: These were regarded as valuable yet harmless products.

dn5:19.1.pli: Atha kho, brāhmaṇa, khattiyā ānuyantā negamā ceva jānapadā ca, amaccā pārisajjā negamā ceva jānapadā ca, brāhmaṇamahāsālā negamā ceva jānapadā ca, gahapatinecayikā negamā ceva jānapadā ca pahūtaṃ sāpateyyaṃ ādāya rājānaṃ mahāvijitaṃ upasaṅkamitvā evamāhaṃsu:
dn5:19.1.eng: Then the aristocrat vassals, ministers and councillors, well-to-do brahmins, and well-off householders came to the king bringing abundant wealth and said,

dn5:19.2.pli: ‘idaṃ, deva, pahūtaṃ sāpateyyaṃ devaññeva uddissābhataṃ, taṃ devo paṭiggaṇhātū’ti.
dn5:19.2.eng: ‘Sire, this abundant wealth is specially for you alone; may Your Highness accept it!’
dn5:19.2.comm: The king’s generosity and sincerity brings out the best in the others.

dn5:19.3.pli: ‘Alaṃ, bho, mamāpidaṃ pahūtaṃ sāpateyyaṃ dhammikena balinā abhisaṅkhataṃ;
dn5:19.3.eng: ‘There’s enough raised for me through regular taxes. Let this be for you; and here, take even more!’

dn5:19.4.pli: tañca vo hotu, ito ca bhiyyo harathā’ti.

dn5:19.5.pli: Te raññā paṭikkhittā ekamantaṃ apakkamma evaṃ samacintesuṃ:
dn5:19.5.eng: When the king turned them down, they withdrew to one side to think up a plan,

dn5:19.6.pli: ‘na kho etaṃ amhākaṃ patirūpaṃ, yaṃ mayaṃ imāni sāpateyyāni punadeva sakāni gharāni paṭihareyyāma.
dn5:19.6.eng: ‘It wouldn’t be proper for us to take this abundant wealth back to our own homes.

dn5:19.7.pli: Rājā kho mahāvijito mahāyaññaṃ yajati, handassa mayaṃ anuyāgino homā’ti.
dn5:19.7.eng: King Mahāvijita is performing a great sacrifice. Let us make an offering as an auxiliary sacrifice.’

dn5:20.1.pli: Atha kho, brāhmaṇa, puratthimena yaññavāṭassa khattiyā ānuyantā negamā ceva jānapadā ca dānāni paṭṭhapesuṃ.
dn5:20.1.eng: Then the aristocrat vassals of town and country set up gifts to the east of the sacrificial enclosure.

dn5:20.2.pli: Dakkhiṇena yaññavāṭassa amaccā pārisajjā negamā ceva jānapadā ca dānāni paṭṭhapesuṃ.
dn5:20.2.eng: The ministers and councillors of town and country set up gifts to the south of the sacrificial enclosure.

dn5:20.3.pli: Pacchimena yaññavāṭassa brāhmaṇamahāsālā negamā ceva jānapadā ca dānāni paṭṭhapesuṃ.
dn5:20.3.eng: The well-to-do brahmins of town and country set up gifts to the west of the sacrificial enclosure.

dn5:20.4.pli: Uttarena yaññavāṭassa gahapatinecayikā negamā ceva jānapadā ca dānāni paṭṭhapesuṃ.
dn5:20.4.eng: The well-off householders of town and country set up gifts to the north of the sacrificial enclosure.

dn5:20.5.pli: Tesupi kho, brāhmaṇa, yaññesu neva gāvo haññiṃsu, na ajeḷakā haññiṃsu, na kukkuṭasūkarā haññiṃsu, na vividhā pāṇā saṅghātaṃ āpajjiṃsu, na rukkhā chijjiṃsu yūpatthāya, na dabbhā lūyiṃsu barihisatthāya.
dn5:20.5.eng: And brahmin, in that sacrifice too no cattle were killed, no goats were killed, and no chickens or pigs were killed. There was no slaughter of various kinds of creatures. No trees were felled for the sacrificial post. No grass was reaped to strew over the place of sacrifice.

dn5:20.6.pli: Yepi nesaṃ ahesuṃ dāsāti vā pessāti vā kammakarāti vā, tepi na daṇḍatajjitā na bhayatajjitā na assumukhā rudamānā parikammāni akaṃsu.
dn5:20.6.eng: No bondservants, servants, or workers did their jobs under threat of punishment and danger, weeping with tearful faces.

dn5:20.7.pli: Atha kho ye icchiṃsu, te akaṃsu, ye na icchiṃsu, na te akaṃsu;
dn5:20.7.eng: Those who wished to work did so, while those who did not wish to did not.

dn5:20.8.pli: yaṃ icchiṃsu, taṃ akaṃsu, yaṃ na icchiṃsu na taṃ akaṃsu.
dn5:20.8.eng: They did the work they wanted to, and did not do what they didn’t want to.

dn5:20.9.eng: The sacrifice was completed with just ghee, oil, butter, curds, honey, and molasses.

dn5:20.10.pli: Iti cattāro ca anumatipakkhā, rājā mahāvijito aṭṭhahaṅgehi samannāgato, purohito brāhmaṇo catūhaṅgehi samannāgato;
dn5:20.10.eng: And so there were four consenting factions, eight factors possessed by King Mahāvijita, four factors possessed by the high priest,

dn5:20.12.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, brāhmaṇa, tividhā yaññasampadā soḷasaparikkhārā”ti.
dn5:20.12.eng: Brahmin, this is called the sacrifice accomplished with three modes and sixteen accessories.”

dn5:21.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, te brāhmaṇā unnādino uccāsaddamahāsaddā ahesuṃ:
dn5:21.1.eng: When he said this, those brahmins made an uproar,
dn5:21.1.comm: Here ends the Buddha’s legendary account of the past.

dn5:21.2.eng: “Hooray for such sacrifice! Hooray for the accomplishment of such sacrifice!”

dn5:21.3.pli: Kūṭadanto pana brāhmaṇo tūṇhībhūtova nisinno hoti.
dn5:21.3.eng: But the brahmin Kūṭadanta sat in silence.
dn5:21.3.comm: The other brahmins are satisfied, but Kūṭadanta senses there is more to it.

dn5:21.4.pli: Atha kho te brāhmaṇā kūṭadantaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ etadavocuṃ:
dn5:21.4.eng: So those brahmins said to him,

dn5:21.5.pli: “kasmā pana bhavaṃ kūṭadanto samaṇassa gotamassa subhāsitaṃ subhāsitato nābbhanumodatī”ti?
dn5:21.5.eng: “How can you not applaud the ascetic Gotama’s fine words?”

dn5:21.6.pli: “Nāhaṃ, bho, samaṇassa gotamassa subhāsitaṃ subhāsitato nābbhanumodāmi.
dn5:21.6.eng: “It’s not that I don’t applaud what he said.

dn5:21.7.pli: Muddhāpi tassa vipateyya, yo samaṇassa gotamassa subhāsitaṃ subhāsitato nābbhanumodeyya.
dn5:21.7.eng: If anyone didn’t applaud such fine words, their head would explode!

dn5:21.8.pli: Api ca me, bho, evaṃ hoti—
dn5:21.8.eng: But, gentlemen, it occurs to me that

dn5:21.9.eng: the ascetic Gotama does not say:

dn5:21.10.pli: ‘evaṃ me sutan’ti vā ‘evaṃ arahati bhavitun’ti vā;
dn5:21.10.eng: ‘So I have heard’ or ‘It ought to be like this.’
dn5:21.10.comm: “So I have heard” (evaṁ me sutaṁ) is the standard opening for Buddhist suttas. This tag was used to indicate that the speaker was not present at the events, but “heard” about them. This is in contrast with the phrase “I heard and learned this in the presence” (sammukhā sutaṁ, sammukhā paṭiggahitaṁ), which is used when reporting a teaching heard directly from the Buddha, eg. SN 55.52:5.1, SN 22.90:9.1, MN 47:10.7, etc.

dn5:21.12.pli: ‘evaṃ tadā āsi, itthaṃ tadā āsi’ tveva bhāsati.
dn5:21.12.eng: ‘So it was then, this is how it was then.’

dn5:21.14.pli: ‘addhā samaṇo gotamo tena samayena rājā vā ahosi mahāvijito yaññassāmi purohito vā brāhmaṇo tassa yaññassa yājetā’ti.
dn5:21.14.eng: the ascetic Gotama at that time must have been King Mahāvijita, the owner of the sacrifice, or else the brahmin high priest who facilitated the sacrifice for him.

dn5:21.15.pli: Abhijānāti pana bhavaṃ gotamo evarūpaṃ yaññaṃ yajitvā vā yājetvā vā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjitā”ti?
dn5:21.15.eng: Does the worthy Gotama recall having performed such a sacrifice, or having facilitated it, and then, when his body broke up, after death, being reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm?”

dn5:21.16.pli: “Abhijānāmahaṃ, brāhmaṇa, evarūpaṃ yaññaṃ yajitvā vā yājetvā vā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjitā, ahaṃ tena samayena purohito brāhmaṇo ahosiṃ tassa yaññassa yājetā”ti.
dn5:21.16.eng: “I do recall that, brahmin. For I myself was the brahmin high priest at that time who facilitated the sacrifice.”
dn5:21.16.comm: This qualifies the story of Mahāvijita as an early canonical Jātaka. There are a small number of such stories in the early suttas, only some of which overlap with the later Jātaka collections, the story of Mahāvijita not being among them.

dn5:22.0.eng: 5. A Regular Gift as an Propitious Sacrifice.

dn5:22.1.pli: “Atthi pana, bho gotama, añño yañño imāya tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṃsataro cā”ti?
dn5:22.1.eng: “But Mister Gotama, apart from that sacrifice accomplished with three modes and sixteen accessories, is there any other sacrifice that has fewer obligations and undertakings, yet is more fruitful and beneficial?”
dn5:22.1.comm: Kūṭadanta is hoping for a better return on his investment. Throughout the suttas, we find a strain of what might be called “spiritual economics”.

dn5:22.2.pli: “Atthi kho, brāhmaṇa, añño yañño imāya tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṃsataro cā”ti.

dn5:22.3.pli: “Katamo pana so, bho gotama, yañño imāya tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṃsataro cā”ti?

dn5:22.4.pli: “Yāni kho pana tāni, brāhmaṇa, niccadānāni anukulayaññāni sīlavante pabbajite uddissa diyyanti;
dn5:22.4.eng: “The regular gifts as propitious sacrifice given specially to ethical renunciates;
dn5:22.4.comm: The anukula (“propitious”) sacrifice is mentioned several times (eg. DN 5:22.4, AN 4.40:2.2). The Pali commentaries interpret it as “in line with (anu-) family (kula)”. But nothing in the contexts connects it with family customs, nor is such a term known in Sanskrit. It seems rather to be a misunderstanding of Sanskrit anukūla, literally “along the riverbank”, and in applied use, “in conformity with”, “favorable to”, as in the favor of the gods. This is the standard reading in Buddhist Sanskrit. Such a sacrifice is characterized, not by family custom, but by harmlessness. Thus anukula means “propitious, favored (by the gods and the Dhamma)”.

dn5:22.5.pli: ayaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, yañño imāya tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṃsataro cā”ti.
dn5:22.5.eng: this sacrifice, brahmin, has fewer obligations and undertakings, yet is more fruitful and beneficial.”

dn5:23.1.pli: “Ko nu kho, bho gotama, hetu ko paccayo, yena taṃ niccadānaṃ anukulayaññaṃ imāya tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya appaṭṭhatarañca appasamārambhatarañca mahapphalatarañca mahānisaṃsatarañcā”ti?
dn5:23.1.eng: “What is the cause, Mister Gotama, what is the reason why those regular gifts as propitious sacrifice have fewer obligations and undertakings, yet are more fruitful and beneficial, compared with the sacrifice accomplished with three modes and sixteen accessories?”

dn5:23.2.pli: “Na kho, brāhmaṇa, evarūpaṃ yaññaṃ upasaṅkamanti arahanto vā arahattamaggaṃ vā samāpannā.
dn5:23.2.eng: “Because neither perfected ones nor those who are on the path to perfection will attend such a sacrifice.

dn5:23.4.pli: Dissanti hettha, brāhmaṇa, daṇḍappahārāpi galaggahāpi, tasmā evarūpaṃ yaññaṃ na upasaṅkamanti arahanto vā arahattamaggaṃ vā samāpannā.
dn5:23.4.eng: Because beatings and throttlings are seen there.
dn5:23.4.comm: This contradicts the description given above.

dn5:23.5.pli: Yāni kho pana tāni, brāhmaṇa, niccadānāni anukulayaññāni sīlavante pabbajite uddissa diyyanti;
dn5:23.5.eng: But the regular gifts as propitious sacrifice given specially to ethical renunciates;

dn5:23.6.pli: evarūpaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, yaññaṃ upasaṅkamanti arahanto vā arahattamaggaṃ vā samāpannā.
dn5:23.6.eng: perfected ones and those who are on the path to perfection will attend such a sacrifice.

dn5:23.8.pli: Na hettha, brāhmaṇa, dissanti daṇḍappahārāpi galaggahāpi, tasmā evarūpaṃ yaññaṃ upasaṅkamanti arahanto vā arahattamaggaṃ vā samāpannā.
dn5:23.8.eng: Because no beatings and throttlings are seen there.

dn5:23.9.pli: Ayaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, hetu ayaṃ paccayo, yena taṃ niccadānaṃ anukulayaññaṃ imāya tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya appaṭṭhatarañca appasamārambhatarañca mahapphalatarañca mahānisaṃsatarañcā”ti.
dn5:23.9.eng: This is the cause, brahmin, this is the reason why those regular gifts as propitious sacrifice have fewer obligations and undertakings, yet are more fruitful and beneficial, compared with the sacrifice accomplished with three modes and sixteen accessories.”

dn5:24.1.pli: “Atthi pana, bho gotama, añño yañño imāya ca tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya iminā ca niccadānena anukulayaññena appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṃsataro cā”ti?
dn5:24.1.eng: “But Mister Gotama, apart from that sacrifice accomplished with three modes and sixteen accessories and those regular gifts as propitious sacrifice, is there any other sacrifice that has fewer obligations and undertakings, yet is more fruitful and beneficial?”

dn5:24.2.pli: “Atthi kho, brāhmaṇa, añño yañño imāya ca tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya iminā ca niccadānena anukulayaññena appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṃsataro cā”ti.

dn5:24.3.pli: “Katamo pana so, bho gotama, yañño imāya ca tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya iminā ca niccadānena anukulayaññena appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṃsataro cā”ti?

dn5:24.4.pli: “Yo kho, brāhmaṇa, cātuddisaṃ saṅghaṃ uddissa vihāraṃ karoti, ayaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, yañño imāya ca tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya iminā ca niccadānena anukulayaññena appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṃsataro cā”ti.
dn5:24.4.eng: “When someone gives a dwelling specially for the Saṅgha of the four quarters.”
dn5:24.4.comm: This means that the dwelling could be used by any Saṅgha member, as opposed to being given to a particular monastic or group. The gift of a dwelling is regarded as the best kind of offering to the Saṅgha.

dn5:25.1.pli: “Atthi pana, bho gotama, añño yañño imāya ca tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya iminā ca niccadānena anukulayaññena iminā ca vihāradānena appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṃsataro cā”ti?
dn5:25.1.eng: “But is there any other sacrifice that has fewer obligations and undertakings, yet is more fruitful and beneficial?”

dn5:25.2.pli: “Atthi kho, brāhmaṇa, añño yañño imāya ca tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya iminā ca niccadānena anukulayaññena iminā ca vihāradānena appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṃsataro cā”ti.

dn5:25.3.pli: “Katamo pana so, bho gotama, yañño imāya ca tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya iminā ca niccadānena anukulayaññena iminā ca vihāradānena appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṃsataro cā”ti?

dn5:25.4.pli: “Yo kho, brāhmaṇa, pasannacitto buddhaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchati, dhammaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchati, saṅghaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchati;
dn5:25.4.eng: “When someone with confident heart goes for refuge to the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha.”

dn5:25.5.pli: ayaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, yañño imāya ca tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya iminā ca niccadānena anukulayaññena iminā ca vihāradānena appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṃsataro cā”ti.

dn5:26.1.pli: “Atthi pana, bho gotama, añño yañño imāya ca tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya iminā ca niccadānena anukulayaññena iminā ca vihāradānena imehi ca saraṇagamanehi appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṃsataro cā”ti?
dn5:26.1.eng: “But is there any other sacrifice that has fewer obligations and undertakings, yet is more fruitful and beneficial?”

dn5:26.2.pli: “Atthi kho, brāhmaṇa, añño yañño imāya ca tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya iminā ca niccadānena anukulayaññena iminā ca vihāradānena imehi ca saraṇagamanehi appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṃsataro cā”ti.

dn5:26.3.pli: “Katamo pana so, bho gotama, yañño imāya ca tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya iminā ca niccadānena anukulayaññena iminā ca vihāradānena imehi ca saraṇagamanehi appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṃsataro cā”ti?

dn5:26.4.eng: “When someone with a confident heart undertakes the training rules

dn5:26.5.pli: pāṇātipātā veramaṇiṃ, adinnādānā veramaṇiṃ, kāmesumicchācārā veramaṇiṃ, musāvādā veramaṇiṃ, surāmerayamajjapamādaṭṭhānā veramaṇiṃ.
dn5:26.5.eng: to refrain from killing living creatures, stealing, sexual misconduct, lying, and beer, wine, and liquor intoxicants.”
dn5:26.5.comm: Thus far the Buddha has described the regular practice of a Buddhist lay person.

dn5:26.6.pli: Ayaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, yañño imāya ca tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya iminā ca niccadānena anukulayaññena iminā ca vihāradānena imehi ca saraṇagamanehi appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṃsataro cā”ti.

dn5:27.1.pli: “Atthi pana, bho gotama, añño yañño imāya ca tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya iminā ca niccadānena anukulayaññena iminā ca vihāradānena imehi ca saraṇagamanehi imehi ca sikkhāpadehi appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṃsataro cā”ti?
dn5:27.1.eng: “But is there any other sacrifice that has fewer obligations and undertakings, yet is more fruitful and beneficial?”

dn5:27.2.pli: “Atthi kho, brāhmaṇa, añño yañño imāya ca tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya iminā ca niccadānena anukulayaññena iminā ca vihāradānena imehi ca saraṇagamanehi imehi ca sikkhāpadehi appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṃsataro cā”ti.

dn5:27.3.pli: “Katamo pana so, bho gotama, yañño imāya ca tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya iminā ca niccadānena anukulayaññena iminā ca vihāradānena imehi ca saraṇagamanehi imehi ca sikkhāpadehi appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṃsataro cā”ti?

dn5:27.4.pli: “Idha, brāhmaṇa, tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṃ sammāsambuddho …pe…
dn5:27.4.eng: It’s when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha …

dn5:27.5.pli: Evaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, bhikkhu sīlasampanno hoti …pe…
dn5:27.5.eng: That’s how a mendicant is accomplished in ethics. …

dn5:27.6.eng: They enter and remain in the first absorption …

dn5:27.7.pli: Ayaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, yañño purimehi yaññehi appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṃsataro ca …pe…
dn5:27.7.eng: This sacrifice has fewer obligations and undertakings than the former, yet is more fruitful and beneficial. …

dn5:27.8.eng: They enter and remain in the second absorption …

dn5:27.11.pli: Ayampi kho, brāhmaṇa, yañño purimehi yaññehi appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṃsataro cāti. …pe…
dn5:27.11.eng: This sacrifice has fewer obligations and undertakings than the former, yet is more fruitful and beneficial. …

dn5:27.12.eng: They project and extend the mind toward knowledge and vision …

dn5:27.13.pli: ayampi kho, brāhmaṇa, yañño purimehi yaññehi appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṃsataro ca …pe…
dn5:27.13.eng: This sacrifice has fewer obligations and undertakings than the former, yet is more fruitful and beneficial.

dn5:27.14.eng: They understand: ‘… there is nothing further for this place.’

dn5:27.15.pli: Ayampi kho, brāhmaṇa, yañño purimehi yaññehi appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṃsataro ca.
dn5:27.15.eng: This sacrifice has fewer obligations and undertakings than the former, yet is more fruitful and beneficial.

dn5:27.16.pli: Imāya ca, brāhmaṇa, yaññasampadāya aññā yaññasampadā uttaritarā vā paṇītatarā vā natthī”ti.
dn5:27.16.eng: And, brahmin, there is no other accomplishment of sacrifice which is better and finer than this.”
dn5:27.16.comm: The entire path may be described as a “sacrifice”.

dn5:28.0.eng: 6. Kūṭadanta Declares Himself a Lay Follower

dn5:28.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, kūṭadanto brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
dn5:28.1.eng: When he had spoken, Kūṭadanta said to the Buddha,

dn5:28.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, bho gotama, nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṃ bhotā gotamena anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
dn5:28.3.eng: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, worthy Gotama has made the Teaching clear in many ways.

dn5:28.4.pli: Esāhaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
dn5:28.4.eng: I go for refuge to the worthy Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.

dn5:28.5.pli: Upāsakaṃ maṃ bhavaṃ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gataṃ.
dn5:28.5.eng: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.

dn5:28.6.pli: Esāhaṃ, bho gotama, satta ca usabhasatāni satta ca vacchatarasatāni satta ca vacchatarīsatāni satta ca ajasatāni satta ca urabbhasatāni muñcāmi, jīvitaṃ demi, haritāni ceva tiṇāni khādantu, sītāni ca pānīyāni pivantu, sīto ca nesaṃ vāto upavāyatū”ti.
dn5:28.6.eng: And these bulls, bullocks, heifers, goats, and rams—seven hundred of each—I release them, I grant them life! Let them eat green grass and drink cool water, and may a cool breeze blow upon them!”
dn5:28.6.comm: Releasing animals remains a Buddhist practice today.

dn5:29.0.eng: 7. The Realization of the Fruit of Stream-Entry

dn5:29.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā kūṭadantassa brāhmaṇassa anupubbiṃ kathaṃ kathesi, seyyathidaṃ—
dn5:29.1.eng: Then the Buddha taught Kūṭadanta step by step, with

dn5:29.2.pli: dānakathaṃ sīlakathaṃ saggakathaṃ; kāmānaṃ ādīnavaṃ okāraṃ saṅkilesaṃ nekkhamme ānisaṃsaṃ pakāsesi.
dn5:29.2.eng: a talk on giving, ethical conduct, and heaven. He explained the drawbacks of sensual pleasures, so sordid and corrupt, and the benefit of renunciation.

dn5:29.3.pli: Yadā bhagavā aññāsi kūṭadantaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ kallacittaṃ muducittaṃ vinīvaraṇacittaṃ udaggacittaṃ pasannacittaṃ, atha yā buddhānaṃ sāmukkaṃsikā dhammadesanā, taṃ pakāsesi—
dn5:29.3.eng: And when he knew that Kūṭadanta’s mind was ready, pliable, rid of hindrances, elated, and confident he explained the special teaching of the Buddhas:

dn5:29.4.eng: suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.

dn5:29.5.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma suddhaṃ vatthaṃ apagatakāḷakaṃ sammadeva rajanaṃ paṭiggaṇheyya;
dn5:29.5.eng: Just as a clean cloth rid of stains would properly absorb dye,

dn5:29.6.pli: evameva kūṭadantassa brāhmaṇassa tasmiññeva āsane virajaṃ vītamalaṃ dhammacakkhuṃ udapādi:
dn5:29.6.eng: in that very seat the stainless, immaculate vision of the Dhamma arose in the brahmin Kūṭadanta:

dn5:29.7.eng: “Everything that has a beginning has an end.”

dn5:30.1.pli: Atha kho kūṭadanto brāhmaṇo diṭṭhadhammo pattadhammo viditadhammo pariyogāḷhadhammo tiṇṇavicikiccho vigatakathaṅkatho vesārajjappatto aparappaccayo satthusāsane bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
dn5:30.1.eng: Then Kūṭadanta saw, attained, understood, and fathomed the Dhamma. He went beyond doubt, got rid of indecision, and became self-assured and independent of others regarding the Teacher’s instructions. He said to the Buddha,

dn5:30.2.pli: “adhivāsetu me bhavaṃ gotamo svātanāya bhattaṃ saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghenā”ti.
dn5:30.2.eng: “Would the worthy Gotama together with the mendicant Saṅgha please accept tomorrow’s meal from me?”

dn5:30.4.pli: Atha kho kūṭadanto brāhmaṇo bhagavato adhivāsanaṃ viditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkāmi.
dn5:30.4.eng: Then, knowing that the Buddha had consented, Kūṭadanta got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.

dn5:30.5.pli: Atha kho kūṭadanto brāhmaṇo tassā rattiyā accayena sake yaññavāṭe paṇītaṃ khādanīyaṃ bhojanīyaṃ paṭiyādāpetvā bhagavato kālaṃ ārocāpesi:
dn5:30.5.eng: And when the night had passed Kūṭadanta had delicious fresh and cooked foods prepared in his own sacrificial enclosure. Then he had the Buddha informed of the time, saying,

dn5:30.6.eng: “It’s time, worthy Gotama, the meal is ready.”

dn5:30.7.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghena yena kūṭadantassa brāhmaṇassa yaññavāṭo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
dn5:30.7.eng: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to the sacrificial enclosure of Kūṭadanta together with the mendicant Saṅgha, where he sat on the seat spread out.

dn5:30.8.pli: Atha kho kūṭadanto brāhmaṇo buddhappamukhaṃ bhikkhusaṅghaṃ paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappesi sampavāresi.
dn5:30.8.eng: Then Kūṭadanta served and satisfied the mendicant Saṅgha headed by the Buddha with his own hands with delicious fresh and cooked foods.

dn5:30.9.pli: Atha kho kūṭadanto brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ bhuttāviṃ onītapattapāṇiṃ aññataraṃ nīcaṃ āsanaṃ gahetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
dn5:30.9.eng: When the Buddha had eaten and washed his hand and bowl, Kūṭadanta took a low seat and sat to one side.

dn5:30.10.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho kūṭadantaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ bhagavā dhammiyā kathāya sandassetvā samādapetvā samuttejetvā sampahaṃsetvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkāmīti.
dn5:30.10.eng: Then the Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired him with a Dhamma talk, after which he got up from his seat and left.
